sentence: After a 126% rally since the March 23 low, at the current price of around $96 per share we believe Manhattan Associates’ stock (NASDAQ: MANH) has reached its near term potential.

Manhattan Associates, which makes software solutions to manage supply chains, inventory, and Omni-channel operations, has seen its stock rally from $43 to $96 off the recent bottom compared to the S&P which moved around 55%.

Its stock is beating the overall markets by a good margin, as investors are positive about the company’s focus on the transition to cloud-first business and overall favorable sentiment about the software industry in general, due to no direct Covid-19 impact.
Further, it is up 20% from levels seen in late 2019.
Manhattan Associates’ stock has surpassed the level it was at before the drop in February due to the coronavirus outbreak becoming a pandemic.
This seems to make it fully valued as, in reality, demand and revenues will likely be lower than last year.
While Manhattan Associates’ revenues grew roughly 4% from 2017 to 2019, the net income was down 26% over the same period.
However, it is not a cause for concern as the company is undergoing a business transition with a focus on being a cloud-first company.
The drop in net income figure is due to higher investment in R&D, cloud operations headcount, infrastructure, and technology.
Although the company had sluggish revenue growth and earnings decreased by 21% over 2017-2019, its P/E multiple has increased.
We believe the stock is unlikely to see a significant upside after the recent gain and the potential weakness from a recession-driven by the Covid outbreak.
Our dashboard ‘What Factors Drove 94% Change In Manhattan Associates Stock Between 2017 And Now?’ has the underlying numbers.
Manhattan Associates’ P/E multiple changed from around 30x in 2017 to 60x at the end of 2019.

While the company’s P/E has further increased to about 72x now, there is a downside risk when the current P/E is compared to levels seen in the past years – P/E of 60x at the end of 2019 and 30x at the end of 2017.
So what’s the likely trigger and timing for the downside?

Manhattan Associates provides software solutions to manage supply chains, inventory, and Omnichannel operations for retailers, wholesalers, manufacturers, logistics providers, and other organizations.
The company derives most of its revenues from maintenance and services business segments – around 82% of the total revenues in FY 2019.
Due to the ongoing crisis, businesses have suffered heavy losses worldwide, leading to reduced IT spending.
This is likely to negatively impact both maintenance and services revenue streams resulting in a decline in the top line.

Further, the company has heavily invested in its strategic initiative to transform into a cloud-first enterprise, which is evident from the drop in earnings over the last 2 years and is likely to continue in the current year as well.
Overall, we believe that Manhattan Associates’ third quarter revenues in October will likely be lower as compared to the year-ago period.
However, over the coming weeks, we expect continued improvement in demand and subdued growth in the number of new Covid-19 cases in the U.S. to buoy market expectations.

Following the Fed stimulus — which helped to set a floor on fear — the market has been willing to “look through” the current weak period and take a longer-term view, with investors now mainly focusing their attention on 2021 results.
Though market sentiment can be fickle, and evidence of a sustained uptick in new cases could spook investors once again.
What if you’re looking for a more balanced portfolio instead?

Here’s a top-quality portfolio to outperform the market, with over 100% return since 2016, versus 55% for the S&P 500, Comprised of companies with strong revenue growth, healthy profits, lots of cash, and low risk.
It has outperformed the broader market year after year, consistently.
